title: Emmie Appl
text: Hello there! I am a Pomona College class of 2025 Molecular Biology major and Japanese minor. Currently, I am working as an undergraduate researcher in the Liu Lab studying mannitol-driven biofilm formation in Vibrio cholerae. Outside of the lab, I am a captain for the Pomona-Pitzer Swimming & Diving team.

title: Valentine’s Day
text:
Show the code
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2024-02-13')


---- Compiling #TidyTuesday Information for 2024-02-13 ----
--- There are 3 files available ---


── Downloading files ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1 of 3: "historical_spending.csv"
  2 of 3: "gifts_age.csv"
  3 of 3: "gifts_gender.csv"


Show the code
historical_spending <- tuesdata$historical_spending

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(historical_spending, aes(x = Year, y = PerPerson)) +
  geom_col() +
  labs(
    x = "Year",
    y = "Average Money Spent per Person ($)"
  )

title: European Drug Development
text:
This data set includes the drugs considered for authorization in the European Union between 1995 and 2023. A generic medicine is developed to be the same as a medicine that has already been authorized, with the same active ingredient(s) and dosage(s) to treat the same condition(s). Accelerated assessment indicates that the medicine is a major interest for public health, so its timeframe for review is 150 evaluation days rather than 210.


Show the code
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2023-03-14')

drugs <- tuesdata$drugs

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(drugs, aes(y = generic)) +
  geom_bar(aes(fill = accelerated_assessment)) +
  labs(
    y = "Generic Medicine",
    x = "Drug Count",
    fill = "Accelerated Assessment"
  )









TidyTuesday 2023-03-14
Data from European Medicines Agency via Miquel Anglada Girotto

title: Valentine’s Day
text:
This data was collected by the National Retail Federation in the United States and explores how consumers celebrate Valentine’s Day from 2010 to 2022.


Show the code
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2024-02-13')

historical_spending <- tuesdata$historical_spending

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(historical_spending, aes(x = Year, y = PerPerson)) +
  geom_col() +
  labs(
    x = "Year",
    y = "Average Money Spent per Person ($)"
  )









TidyTuesday 2024-02-13
Data from the National Retail Federation via Sunja aa Kaggle

title: String Analysis
text:
Show the code
library(friends)
library(tidyverse)

friends |>
  group_by(speaker) |>
  summarize(count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 700 × 2
   speaker          count
   <chr>            <int>
 1 Rachel Green      9307
 2 Ross Geller       9157
 3 Chandler Bing     8462
 4 Monica Geller     8440
 5 Joey Tribbiani    8171
 6 Phoebe Buffay     7499
 7 Scene Directions  6060
 8 #ALL#              347
 9 Mike Hannigan      330
10 Richard Burke      281
# ℹ 690 more rows




Show the code
questions <- friends |>
    select(text, speaker) |>
    filter(str_detect(speaker, "Rachel Green|Monica Geller|Phoebe Buffay|Joey Tribbiani$|Chandler Bing|Ross Geller")) |>
    filter(str_detect(text, "\\?")) |>
    group_by(speaker) |>
    summarize(num_questions = n())
  

questions


# A tibble: 6 × 2
  speaker        num_questions
  <chr>                  <int>
1 Chandler Bing           2628
2 Joey Tribbiani          2753
3 Monica Geller           2806
4 Phoebe Buffay           2157
5 Rachel Green            2923
6 Ross Geller             2990


Who asks the most questions?
